title: Panama-affected Qld farmers want more help
text:
View Photo 

Two Queensland banana farmers affected by a devastating fungal disease are still out of pocket despite being awarded more than $650,000 in assistance, their lawyer says. 
The Robsons' property in Tully and the Reppels' farm in Mareeba were quarantined earlier this year after testing positive for soil-borne fungus Panama Tropical Race 4. 
While the positive result at the Mareeba farm was later proved false, the growers have now been compensated a combined figure of $684,243 - funded by the federal and state governments, and the Australian Banana Growers' Council. 
The farmers' lawyer, Ian Conrad, said they appreciated the payment but it didn't go far enough. 
"Both families have incurred considerable cost in complying with strict quarantine procedures," he said. 
"Further compensation is required if the Robsons and the Reppels are not to be left out of pocket." 
A joint release from federal Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce and Queensland Agriculture and Fisheries Minister Bill Byrne said Tuesday's sum was final. 
But Mr Conrad said he had been assured by Mr Byrne's department that the payment negotiations would continue. 
He would not give an approximate figure as to how much more the farmers would need. 
"That's something we'd have to discuss with the department," he said. 
One-sixteenth of the Robsons' farm was destroyed in biosecurity efforts and Mr Conrad claims it will take both families' crops several months to return to normal. 
The Mareeba farm was quarantined for more than two weeks and the Tully farm was reopened after almost two months. 
Mr Conrad said the families were told they would receive the total assistance amount in one payment rather than the $200,000 up-front sum announced.
